conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light; shape and size depend on object shape and light source position.
Position of shadow is determined by direction of light rays relative to the object.
Shadows A, B, C, and D are currently cast on the ground by the light source positioned above and slightly behind the objects.
When the light source moves forward, the angle of the light rays relative to the objects changes.
Shadows will shift position and may change in size depending on the new angle of the light rays.
As the light source moves forward, shadows will move backward (towards the objects) because light rays will come from a more forward direction.
Shadows will appear to move closer to the objects.
Size of the shadows will depend on the new angle of the light rays.
If the light source moves directly above the objects, shadows will become smaller and more concentrated directly beneath the objects.
If the light source moves forward but not directly above, shadows will still become smaller but may not be directly beneath the objects.
Shadows A, B, C, and D will move backward, closer to the objects.
Shadows will become smaller as the light source moves forward and above the objects.
If the light source moves forward, above the objects, shadows A, B, C, and D will move backward (towards the objects) and become smaller.
